What I would say is, that with Confederation we shall be in a better position for self-defence, and to aid the Mother Country under certain exi- cies, than we are at the present time. Having Confederation, the Central Govern- ment will be in a position to have its orders carried out over its whole territory ; and when the question of defence comes up, it will not be obliged to consult four or ﬁve diﬁ‘erent legislaturœ, but it will be able to organise our defences immediately and without ob- struction. It is of no mall importance for the inhabitants of a country to have a standing in foreign countries, and not to be treated as men of inferior position. When Canadians go to London or elsewhere out of their own country, they have no recognized posi- tion, because we are only a simple colony.
